In the entire military history
of the world, it is doubtful wheth6r a more ingenius and intricate
system of military science and
tactics was ever evolved than the
collection of gems from the battalion mid-years that adorned the
military bulletin board last week.
It has given .some members of the
battalion not a little worry to
think that Major Guild could not
appreciate the intense strategic
significance of the solutions they
invented for military problems.
A connoiseur will note with ecstacy the dashes of futurism and
impressions (of the vaguest and
weirdest kind) to be found in the
collection. The complete emancipation from style, the unsimplefied
spelling, the delicate distinctions,
the unconscious humor, the unconventional figures, and the sublime speculation with facts are
irresistibly alluring. The research
that was required to uncover
many of these mysteries must
have been tremendous. For example, how many -students—yea,
even professors—of American history knew that the greatest secretaries of war were George Washington and -Andrew Jackson. Startling, courageous, sensational! In

enumerating the six principal
wars of the United States, the
scandal is bared of the unrecorded
"War with France in 1849" and
"War in Ohio with the Indians."
The War College might do well
to listen to this wholesome advice
and novel directions for cleaning
a rifle.
"When you clean the rifle, work
towards the nozzle."
"After shooting the rifle, it'
should be cleaned out with soda
water."
CC.
. . . he should keep on
cleaning the rifle by shoving woolen rags into it."
"If the inside of the barrel peels
off, it should be treated with ammonia Solution." .
"The rifle is the soldier's best
friend and worst enemy, and a
whole lot more important than he
is." (Very subtle).
"The acid must be kept from
itching the barrel."
"You may break your own neck,
but not the rifle's!" (Denoting a
spirit of heroic sacrifice).
Some new phases of rear guard
work are treated by the young Napoleons:
"The rear guard must stop the
enemy from getting on their
heels.'" (Simile of the (lance).
"Obstructions are put up by the
engineers and completed by the
mounted arm."
"Cavalry may be employed to
disadvantage vhen necessary."
(Resourceful).
A notable example of a beautiful hyperboli is the following definition of "lands." "They are the
little spikes in the muzzle that
keep the bullet straight." Not
even Edison had thought of that.
There is a bewitching uncertainty
or a clayonic tendency to compromise in this idea of a sentry
squad : "One man is placed probably 10 or 15 or 20 or 25 or 30
, yards more or less as the occasion
demands ahead Of the sentry
squad."
But the greatest and most
valuable collection of information
deals with the hand signals, the
execution of which will interest
especially all double-jointed, boneless men, not to mention contortionists. To signal "Commence
Firing":
"Place hand in front of belt
buckle palm down, then with the
wrist move it out and in rapidly.'
"The arm is held straight down
• from the shoulder and stiff, and is
moved in a semi-circle before the
body about the waist line."
"Extend arm toward men to
whom order is given and describe
vertical circles."
"Make a fist at the enemy."
"To cease firing":
"The man giving. the command
puts his hand over his place with
thumb down."
"The open hand is brought to
the waist across the eyes."
"Put wrist in front of forehead
and move face slowly up and
down."

"Alec" Wolfe.

One more name was added to
the long list of Hopkins men in the
service, and one more leader was
lost to the undergraduate student
body at Homewood when "Alec"
Wolfe—taking leave of his Alma
Mater he has served so faithfully
for all but four years—headed for
a ground school of the Naval Aviation Corps. Since last spring we
have learned to expect shocks and
sudden losses, but last week we experienced a sense of loss that bordered closely on a feeling of depair. We knew only too well that
we were losing a leader whose
place it would be difficult,. if not
impossible, to fill. We almost forgot to be proud that he was entering the service of his country, that
he was entering a branch of the
service in which there was room
for only the cream of the nation's
youth—into which it was a privilege and an honor to be accepted.
If any man at Homewood could
be called a student leader, it was
"Alec" Wolfe. As president of the
Hopkins circle of the Omicron
Delta Kappa, as head of the General Athletic Association, and as
captain of the lacrosse team, he

held as many prominent positions
as it is physically possible for one
man to hold down with any degree
of credit. He won his"H" in football last fall, was a member of the
Debating Council, had previously
served as president of his class and
in numerous other capacities. He
was interested in anything and
everything that he thought would
further the interests of Hopkins.
Wherever he thought he could be
of some personal service, he offered himself and gave the best that
was in him. He upheld the dignity
and honor of the high offices to
which he was elected in a manner
that won the complete confidence
and respect of his fellow students.
A typical example of "Alec"
Wolfe's loyalty to his Alma Mater
is the story of how he won his "H"
in football. When the call for football candidates went out last
fall—Hopkins, we are proud to
say, did not subscribe to the convenient "informal football" program—it was evident that, in view
of the loss of so many Varsity men
who had entered the service, a
great number of new men would
have to learn the game if Hopkins
was to have a representative team.
Although he had never in his life
played a game of football (unless
class games could be called football), "Alec" was one of the first
candidates to report to the coach
for duty. He was light and he had
no experience, but he worked and
he worked hard, and won a berth
on a team that outfought, if it did
not outplay every team it faced.
"Alec" contributed not a little, especially in pulling forward
passes out of the air and in jacking up the spirit of the team to
the success, in spite of its defeats,
of the 1917 football team.
As a member in his freshman
year of one of the greatest Hopkins lacrosse teams and as captain
of the 1918 team he lived up to his
family name as a lacrosse star and
won a high place for himself
among Hopkins' galaxy of lacrosse
men. He always stood for the highest standards of sportsmanship
and was ever a credit to the team
of which he was a member and to
the University which .he represented. His name stands high in
the athletic history of Hopkins.
Unassuming, modest, and serenely calm, but sincere, deeply
earnest, and ever-willing, "Alec"
Wolfe served the University as
few men ever do. He will shed
glory upon the branch of the service he has entered, as he has shed
glory through his services and
through his conduct, upon his
Alma Mater.

The Internationality of the Tocqueville
Contest.

In these times of fervid nationalism, it is refreshing to note instances of non-belligerent international significance, of events that
breathe the spirit of world-fraternity that we all look forward to
at the end of the war. The Tocquevile contest has been traditionally
international, in the sense that the
medal is awarded by a Frenchman, Baron de Coubertin, in honor
of a fellow countryman, the famous Alexis de Tocqueville, to the
students of an AmePican University. But the successful competition of Thomas L. Hsi, a Chinese
student, in the preliminary trials
makes the contest this year more
international than ever before.
The fact that a Chinese student,
of whom there has always been a
representative colony at Hopkins,
has for the first time taken active
part in an undergraduate activity
is as noteworthy as the scholarly
feat of a Chinese young man
making a public speech in a foreign tongue. Hsi has set up a
precedent that we hope to see followed. When Chinese students are
willing to take part in our games
and competitions, there will grow
up a corresponding international
friendship that will withstand the
hardest tests.
The enthusiasm and earnestness
with which Hsi entered the preliminary trials augurs well for his
success in the final contest, which
will take place in the early part of
April. THE NEWS-LETTER extends
to Hsi its sincere and heaity congratulations on his success in the
tryouts, and its best wishes for
success in the final contest.

----Uniform, Arms and General Equipment
Subjected to the Unfailing Scrutiny
of Commandant—Precedent
Established.

The monthly muster inspection
and review of the battalion was
held on Thursday, February 28.
The entire R. 0. T. C. Unit—Staff,
Infantry Division, and Drum
Corps—turned out on Gilman
Campus. A review preceded, and
then came an inspection and muster. The inspection was as rigid
as could be; and although the appearance and condition of the battalion was, on the whole, satisfactory, still the commandant was
not well pleased with the numerous dirty leggins, soiled clothes,
and missing insignia. The discipline of the battalion, however,
was beyond reproach, the behavior
of the men, splendid. Next time,
it is hoped, the commandant will
find a perfect inspection.
• At a meeting of the R. 0. T. C.
Advisory Board last week, the
question of excusing baseball men
from drill was brought up. As a
result, the following motion was
passed:
"In the opinion of this board it
is not possible to make any
changes whatever in the present
schedule of drills or any other
military exercises of the R. 0. T.
C. Unit of this University for purposes of athletic activities."
The subject of the preceding
week's drill, the conduct of an
outpost, was continued on Monday of last week. This time each
company placed a line of cossack
posts. The muddy ground and the
murkiness of the weather added
to the reality of the exercises; and
some men even went so far as to
claim that they preferred the
trenches. At any rate, the men
are rapidly learning the duties of
a sentinel and are fast acquiring
a soldierly way of doing things.
At the Wednesday lecture Major
Guild discussed the subject of interior guard duty. He pointed out
the great importance of the soldier's knowing how to conduct
himself when on guard duty; and
he emphasized the fact that every
man in the battalion is expected
to know thoroughly the 12 duties
of a sentinel, as embodied in the
general orders for interior guard
duty.

served as president of his class and
in numerous other capacities. He
was interested in anything and
everything that he thought would
further the interests of Hopkins.
Wherever he thought he could be
of some personal service, he offered himself and gave the best that
was in him. He upheld the dignity
and honor of the high offices to
which he was elected in a manner
that won the complete confidence
and respect of his fellow students.
A typical example of "Alec"
Wolfe's loyalty to his Alma Mater
is the story of how he won his "H"
in football. When the call for football candidates went out last
fall—Hopkins, we are proud to
say, did not subscribe to the convenient "informal football" program—it was evident that, in view
of the loss of so many Varsity men
who had entered the service, a
great number of new men would
have to learn the game if Hopkins
was to have a representative team.
Although he had never in his life
played a game of football (unless
class games could be called football), "Alec" was one of the first
candidates to report to the coach
for duty. He was light and he had
no experience, but he worked and
he worked hard, and won a berth
on a team that outfought, if it did
not outplay every team it faced.
"Alec" contributed not a little, especially in pulling forward
passes out of the air and in jacking up the spirit of the team to
the success, in spite of its defeats,
of the 1917 football team.
As a member in his freshman
year of one of the greatest Hopkins lacrosse teams and as captain
of the 1918 team he lived up to his
family name as a lacrosse star and
won a high place for himself
among Hopkins' galaxy of lacrosse
men. He always stood for the highest standards of sportsmanship
and was ever a credit to the team
of which he was a member and to
the University which .he represented. His name stands high in
the athletic history of Hopkins.
Unassuming, modest, and serenely calm, but sincere, deeply
earnest, and ever-willing, "Alec"
Wolfe served the University as
few men ever do. He will shed
glory upon the branch of the service he has entered, as he has shed
glory through his services and
through his conduct, upon his
Alma Mater.

The Internationality of the Tocqueville
Contest.

In these times of fervid nationalism, it is refreshing to note instances of non-belligerent international significance, of events that
breathe the spirit of world-fraternity that we all look forward to
at the end of the war. The Tocquevile contest has been traditionally
international, in the sense that the
medal is awarded by a Frenchman, Baron de Coubertin, in honor
of a fellow countryman, the famous Alexis de Tocqueville, to the
students of an AmePican University. But the successful competition of Thomas L. Hsi, a Chinese
student, in the preliminary trials
makes the contest this year more
international than ever before.
The fact that a Chinese student,
of whom there has always been a
representative colony at Hopkins,
has for the first time taken active
part in an undergraduate activity
is as noteworthy as the scholarly
feat of a Chinese young man
making a public speech in a foreign tongue. Hsi has set up a
precedent that we hope to see followed. When Chinese students are
willing to take part in our games
and competitions, there will grow
up a corresponding international
friendship that will withstand the
hardest tests.
The enthusiasm and earnestness
with which Hsi entered the preliminary trials augurs well for his
success in the final contest, which
will take place in the early part of
April. THE NEWS-LETTER extends
to Hsi its sincere and heaity congratulations on his success in the
tryouts, and its best wishes for
success in the final contest.

----Uniform, Arms and General Equipment
Subjected to the Unfailing Scrutiny
of Commandant—Precedent
Established.

The monthly muster inspection
and review of the battalion was
held on Thursday, February 28.
The entire R. 0. T. C. Unit—Staff,
Infantry Division, and Drum
Corps—turned out on Gilman
Campus. A review preceded, and
then came an inspection and muster. The inspection was as rigid
as could be; and although the appearance and condition of the battalion was, on the whole, satisfactory, still the commandant was
not well pleased with the numerous dirty leggins, soiled clothes,
and missing insignia. The discipline of the battalion, however,
was beyond reproach, the behavior
of the men, splendid. Next time,
it is hoped, the commandant will
find a perfect inspection.
• At a meeting of the R. 0. T. C.
Advisory Board last week, the
question of excusing baseball men
from drill was brought up. As a
result, the following motion was
passed:
"In the opinion of this board it
is not possible to make any
changes whatever in the present
schedule of drills or any other
military exercises of the R. 0. T.
C. Unit of this University for purposes of athletic activities."
The subject of the preceding
week's drill, the conduct of an
outpost, was continued on Monday of last week. This time each
company placed a line of cossack
posts. The muddy ground and the
murkiness of the weather added
to the reality of the exercises; and
some men even went so far as to
claim that they preferred the
trenches. At any rate, the men
are rapidly learning the duties of
a sentinel and are fast acquiring
a soldierly way of doing things.
At the Wednesday lecture Major
Guild discussed the subject of interior guard duty. He pointed out
the great importance of the soldier's knowing how to conduct
himself when on guard duty; and
he emphasized the fact that every
man in the battalion is expected
to know thoroughly the 12 duties
of a sentinel, as embodied in the
general orders for interior guard
duty.
